./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Will refer to JavaScript as JS.
[Talk about cognitive load and how I'm trying to keep that as minimal as possible, metaphors are meant to provide a familiar thing to attach concepts to, to help reduce cognitive load]
I'm writing this as a way to try and share my knowledge in my own way, where I have picked up some ideas that might help others learn JavaScript (and programming in general) more easily.
I will use terms that you may not be familiar with, but will link them to a glossary. It is not required that you know or understand these terms as they are introduced, but they will help you be able to communicate with others mor effectively. Other terms may be discussed more in later sections.

book/first-steps/getting-started.html.title: Getting Started
book/first-steps/getting-started.html.body:
Getting Started
Before getting into anything else, let's first setup a very simple development environment. There are tons of tools available on the internet for testing out JS; however, many of them incorporate HTML and CSS. We will focus on those later and don't need to worry about them right now. For now I will recommend that you use the following site/tool:
https://jscomplete.com/repl
This page on this site let's you only write and run JS.
Once you've got that opened up type put the following into the left editor area:

console.log('My first line of JavaScript');

Then click he play button or press Cmd/Ctrl + Enter. This will run the JS you have in the left column. And you will be able to see the output in the right column.
Going forward, any place that you type code will be called "your editor" and the place where you see output will be aptly called "your output" or "the console" (yep, that's related to the console.log from above).

book/first-steps/the-basics.html.title: The Basics
book/first-steps/the-basics.html.body:
The Basics
Any programing language is about having a bunch of small pieces of knowledge about how the language works (and how programs work in general). These little piece of knowledge are often referred to as "tools". The more tools you have, the more you can do. You will be able to use these tools in ever increasing combinations with each other to produce better, smarter, and more efficient programs. So let's jump right into building up your box of tools; the first one of which you have already used.
Seeing Something Happen
This first tool has a lot more going on than I will cover initially, so I'll just ask that you use it as I am giving it to you and, for now, simply accept that it does what we need it to. It will be covered later more in depth once you understand some additional concepts.
console.log()

This line written as is will technically do something, though you wont actually be able to see the result. To make it ever so slightly more interesting let's put something between the parentheses.
console.log(42)

If you run this example in your editor, you will see the number 42 appear in your output.
All we did here was tell JS to output (or log) a number, and thats exactly what it did. You can log literally anything (except [keywords]) in JS, and this will be very handy when you find that your program is not working as you expect. We will cover more about console.log in future sections, but for now feel free to play with logging things to the console. Here are a few examples that will make more sense shortly:
console.log(3.14)

console.log('This is a string')

console.log(true)

Code in Your Head
Something that will come with experience will be the critically important ability to run/execute the code you are looking at in your head. This is just another tool that you will develop over time. If you are now able to look at a line like:
console.log('This puts something in the console')

And can then imagine that text appearing in your output, then you're already on your way.
???
You may ask yourself (or try to ask me, to which I will have no reply as I cannot hear you) things like:
1) Can I do it this way?
2) Why do I have to do it this way?
3) I don't like how this works, can I do it differently?
And to answer those questions:
1) Maybe, but probably not.
2) Because that's how it is done.
3) Again, maybe, there are a lot of ways to do the same thing in JavaScript, as you will learn over time.
I will attempt to make it clear why things are done the way they are and try to give you some ways to help remember these things.
Variables
Let me start with another metaphor. Imagine you have an index card. There are two things you can do with this index card:
1) Give it a title/name.
2) Write some information (also called a value) on it.
When you are writing on this index card you are using a pen for the name and a pencil for the value. Once you've written the name, it cannot be changed. However since you wrote the value in pencil, there is nothing stopping you from changing it whenever you want. Use that mental model for now as we talk about variables.
Name
The name of a variable can be whatever you want with a few restrictions:
1) It should only contain letters, numbers, and underscores.
2) It cannot begin with a number (but may contain numbers).
3) It cannot contain any spaces.
There are a few exceptions to other characters that you can use for variable names (you can even use emoji... try it out to get it out of your system, but please, never ever do it for a real program), but at this point there is no reason you should need to use anything other than letters and numbers. I won't event be using underscores in my examples.
You will see me use what is called camel case. This just refers to using multiple words in the name of a variable, removing the spaces, and capitalizing the first letter of each word after the first word. Here are a few examples:

theNumber
theBestString
aTacoTruck
samsCafe

Value
Here is a variable with just a name:
var myFirstVariable

Think of it as having no value, or that you have an index card with just a name at the top, but you haven't written any value down on it. You can either give the variable a value immediately after giving it a name, or you can set it aside and give it a value later. Either way, you will need to use the equals sign to assign a value to a variable. Here are both of those options, respectively:
var myFirstVariable = 42

var myFirstVariable
myfirstVariable = 42

Now would be a good time to mention that most code is executed from right to left. Meaning the value on the right of the equals sign will be assigned to the variable on the left. It absolutely will not work the other way, by having the value on the left and the variable name on the right.
Types
Numbers
There are two types of numbers: integers and floats. There are limits to the rang of numbers you can represent, so keep in mind if you try to use a number that is too large, too small, or even just right, you might see some weird behavior from your program.
Integer
An integer is any whole number. You can represent whole numbers well over a trillion, but if you get too high or too low, and add or subtract from those numbers, you'll notice that your value doesn't change at all. I'll leave it up to you to figure out what the actual integer limits are.
Float
A float is any number with some decimal place. You will definitely encounter The weirdness with floats at some point while running your code. To demonstrate this, run the following line:
console.log(2.2 + 1.1)

You'll see that what gets output it almost what you wanted, but computers have their limits with how they can represent numbers. Just like the integer has an upper an lower limit it can represent, floats have fractions of numbers that they can't quite represent. But they do try to get as close as possible.
Character
A character is a single letter or symbol (for example anything that you can see on your keyboard can be a character)
String
A string is a series of characters. If that sentence doesn't quite make sense, try to imagine popcorn lined up with a single strand of thread connecting each piece of popcorn. On each piece of popcorn you can write a single character. Together all the pieces of popcorn make up a string. This could be a sentence, a person's name, or a color. A string can be anything you can create by typing on your keyboard.
Boolean
A boolean is is a true or false value.
Math
If you ran the console.log above, you've already done a bit of math in JS. Math in most programming languages is the same, with the same operators that you might have used in a math class: + - * / ( ). There is a concept that is worth understanding called [order of operations]. This is simply the order in which each mathematical operator gets used. Rather than trying to explain this concept to you, try playing around with adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing some numbers. If you don't get the result you might have expected try figuring out what order things happened in to give you the result you got, and then add some parentheses to get the result you were originally expecting. Heres an example:
console.log(1 + 2 * 3)

You might expect this to give you 9:
1) 1 + 2 = 3
2) 3 * 3 = 9
But you actually get 7. What is happening is that the multiplication is occurring before the addition:
1) 2 * 3 = 6
2) 1 + 6 = 7
To get 9 you simply need to add parentheses around the addition:
console.log((1 + 2) * 3)

Parentheses always take the highest precedence when doing math.

book/first-steps/comments.html.title: Comments
book/first-steps/comments.html.body:
Comments
The ability to write good comments is an invaluable tool to have under your belt. Whether it is code that you have written, or code that others have written, everyone will be doing a service to themselves and others by writing effective comments about their code. This section will touch on different types of comments and ways of commenting, and how to effectively use them.
What are Comments
In their most basic form, comments are a way of adding information to your code that will in no way every be executed.
Imagine writing and editing an essay. As you write your essay you will likely be using other sources to back up an argument or information that you are including in it, and they will need to be cited somewhere outside the body of the essay. Or, as you read through your essay, after writing the first draft, you may notice spelling, grammar, and punctuation issues. And as you see these issues you may be inclined to notate somewhere near them as a reminder to yourself to go back and make changes when you work on your next draft.
Both the citations and notations around mistakes are akin to code comments. As citations and notations for mistakes do not change the content that you have written in your essay, they do serve as a reference for someone else or yourself when you revisit your essay at a later time (this could be a few seconds if you're on a roll, or just before the essay is due if your a procrastinator).
Just as citations and notations do not change your essay, code comments do not change a program; they simply serve as a reminder to yourself and others for why you have done something the way you have (for good or bad), how something works (possibly referencing a website with more information), or even reminders for possible future enhancements to the program. Or if you're feeling cheeky, comments can be used for a bit of humor for other programmers to find one day (an older version of you included).
Disclaimer: A fair amount of this section will be subjective, so read it with an open mind and come to your own conclusions about you think makes for good comments in code. Finding a balance between what works well for you, but also others reading your code, can be a challenging task.
Types of Comments
In JS there are two types of comments: line comments, and block comments. I feel like this is a good place for a joke here, but sadly nothing good is coming to mind.
Line comments
This type of comment looks like this:
// I am a comment, and I do nothing other than communicate information to someone reading me.

These comments are often found on their own line, but can also be included at the end of a line. If you are going to write a line comment, I will advocate for always doing it directly above the line (or lines) that it pertains to.
// Adding "a" and "b", this is probably obvious, but this is also an example...
var sum = a + b

This can also be done as:
var sum = a + b // Adding "a" and "b", this is probably obvious, but this is also an example...

But again, I'm going to ask that you avoid this where possible. I am of the opinion that putting the comment above the code helps reduce cognitive load.
Block Comments
This type of comment looks like this:
/*
I am also a comment, but slightly cooler...
because I can span multiple lines.
This makes reading me a good bit easier when there is a lot of information to convey.
*/

Like the comment itself mentions, these are usually used when you need to explain something by going in depth or using a significant number of words. They also allow you to easily give examples of code within the comment, which will be demonstrated later.
/*
I have no idea how this works, but it does.
I copied and pasted it from "crazycode.com/get-it-done" and it just worked.
SO as a warning to anyone reading this... DO NOT TOUCH OR YOU WILL BREAK THE UNIVERSE
*/
var wtf = ((4 >> 5 + 6) 
What to Talk About in Comments
There is nothing stopping you from putting whatever you're in the mood for inside a comment, but I will try and give you a few guidelines to help you be productive with them.
Why (did I do this)
Often with new problems you may not know how best to approach a solution to them, so you try your best with what you do know. You might easily recognize that you are not solving the problem in an optimal way, so a constructive comment might explain why you're doing what you're doing, and suggest to the reader that it might be improved upon. On the other hand if you are a more experienced programmer you might want to leave notes for others that might be less experienced, and explain why you made the choices you made and why they are good choices.
How (to do this) or (I did this)
These types of comments talk about how to use something. This something could be a (library)[../appendix/glossary.md#library] that someone else has written, or code that you have written that exists elsewhere. It could even explain the approach you've taken to accomplish whatever it is you set out to do.
Todo
This is often used in a comment as a reminder that something is non-existent and needs to be written, that is it incomplete, or that it works as it is, but could use improvement.
That's Not All
There are a number of other ways to use comments, which will be covered in the intermediate section.
Final Comments (get it...)
I will allow you one exception for adding comments in less desireable ways. And that is to get a feel for how comments work when added to your code by experimenting with where they can be added. Ultimately though your goal should be to find what works best for you and anyone you might work with.

book/first-steps/everything-is-a-value.h.title: Everything is a Value
book/first-steps/everything-is-a-value.h.body:
Everything is a Value
The title of this section is a bit of an over generalization, but not by much. What I'm trying to convey is that almost anything in JavaScript can be assigned to a variable. So technically, almost everything is a value. I'll give a few examples here with things that have been covered up to this point. But the best way to figure out what is and is not a value, and what you can do by assigning it to a variable, is to try it.
The Basics
numbers, strings, boolean
Covered Later
functions, objects
null, undefined

book/first-steps/making-decisions.html.title: Making Decisions

book/first-steps/debugging.html.title: Debugging
book/first-steps/debugging.html.body:
Debugging
This will inarguably be the most valuable tool of any programmer. No one writes perfect code that works the first time and that has no flaws. In any language, every programmer will introduce bugs into the code they write. This is just a fact of life. There is a ray of hope however, and that ray is the ability of a programmer to be able to debug their (and others) code.
Hopefully you've been playing with writing some of your own code up to this point, and even more hopefully you've been using console.log to see what it is doing. Even more points if you've run into an issue, and used console.log to help you figure out what was going wrong (by logging out something you might not normally have).
If you have not happened to try this out, then I hope you find the next few sections enlightening into the ways of debugging and benefit of mastering it as a skill.
What is a Bug
For as long as I have been writing code, I will still find myself introducing bugs relatively frequently. Most of the time they will be caught through manual and automated testing. As I write this, I am trying to come up with some examples of bugs, but finding it difficult to intentionally introduce one that might be a common beginners mistake.
How to Debug
Practice. Practice. Practice. You will see errors or unexpected behavior in your programs and then have to figure out why the thing that is happening is happening. There are a few common types of bugs you might run into.
Syntax Errors
These are usually the easiest to fix. There are a lot of code editors out there, and most of them will support syntax highlighting as well code analysis to let you know that when you have written some code that it knows just will not work. If you are not using one of these more advanced editors then whatever is running your code will immediately inform you of syntax errors and stop trying to run your program. The solution is usually as simple as correcting your code.
Run Time Errors
These errors can be a little harder to track down. You will definitely see an error output in the console for these types of errors. And while the output will definitely tell you what happened, it can be harder to track down why it happened.
Logic Errors
These are definitely the trickiest to figure out. These present themselves as unexpected behavior, so you won't see any error output to the console.

book/intermediate-topics/arrays.html.title: Arrays
book/intermediate-topics/arrays.html.body:
Arrays
Arrays are actually quite simple. You quite use them every day without actually realizing it. You can think of literally anything that is a list as an array. You might make a list of strings, a todo list. Or a list of numbers, an expense report. You can easily add an remove items from either of these lists as you either complete items or spend more money. Here are some JS arrays:
var emptyArray = []
var anArray = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
var aStringArray = [
    'I',
    'Love',
    'Arrays!'
]
var mixedArray = [
    42,
    'Six',
    777,
    'Why would you do this?',
    3.14
]

Let's use this array for the next for examples:
var expenses = [
    4.78,
    77.89,
    20.50,
    9.99,
    86.90
]

View Items
// This will output the entire array
console.log(expenses)

You can measure arrays:
// .length tells you how many items are in the array
// In the case of expenses, 5
console.log(expenses.length)

You can access items in an array. Items are accessed by their "index". The index is simply a number that indicates an items position in an array, and they always start at 0 for the first item. You can think of the index as the number of items away from the first item it is. So the first item is 0 items away from the first item! The second item is 1 item away from the first item. And so on.
// Using the original array, output each of the items
// There are much better ways of doing this which you'll see soon
console.log(expenses[0])
console.log(expenses[1])
console.log(expenses[2])
console.log(expenses[3])
console.log(expenses[4])

Add/Change Items
You can add items to an array. The term of this is pushing something onto an array. Imagine a stack of things that is just slightly taller than you are, if you want to add something to it, you're going to have to reach up and "push" it on to the array.
// We just made a new purchase, so add it
expenses.push(5.99)
console.log(expenses.length)

You can also change an item at a specific index. Let's add 10.00 to the 9.99 item.
expenses[3] += 10.00

console.log(expenses[3])

Remove Items
Let's say we returned the 77.89 item and we want to remove it from the array. We do this by using the splice function. It's not the best name to describe what it does (though it can do more than remove a single item). Splice removes "y" items, starting from position "x".
array.splice(x, y)

// The item we want to remove is at index 1,
// and we only want to remove the one item
expenses.splice(1, 1)

console.log(expenses.length)
console.log(expenses)

If you specifically want to remove the last item from the array, you can "pop" it off. Imagine that it is stuck on the array and when you remove the item at the last index, it "pops" off.
var poppedItem = array.pop()
console.log(poppedItem)

Keywords
This is a list of all the key words broken down by JavaScript version
ES6

break
case
catch
class

debugger

else

extends
finally

in

void

Library
A library is
Maintainability
This is a subjective rating to gauge how maintainable a piece of software is.
Nesting
Nesting is
Truthiness
This is a list of all of the types of values in JS and whether they evaluate to true or false
Things that evaluate to true

true
1
-1
"All non empty strings"
"false"
"0"
"null"
"undefined"
"NaN"


infinity
-infinity
[]
{}

Things that evaluate to false

false
0
"" (an empty string)
null
undefined
NaN
